awd_titl_txt: Investigating phloem structure function relations in vivo
awd_abstract_narration: The phloem of higher plants is a long distance translocation system that distributes assimilates generated by photosynthesis to tissues such as fruits and underground organs. The majority of the nutrients consumed by humans have been translocated through the phloem. In addition, the phloem serves as a long distance signaling system. It can roughly be compared to a combination of the human circulatory and nervous system. Due to its high concentration of sugars and other nutrients, it represents the primary target for pests such as aphids, mealybugs, and leafhoppers. Furthermore, plant viruses use the phloem to spread  throughout the plant. This causes substantial economic damage and leads to the use of high amounts of protective chemicals. Despite the central role the phloem plays in plant pest interactions, the current knowledge of the underlying processes is poor. By employing newly-developed molecular and cell biological tools, this project aims to elucidate cellular and subcellular processes in phloem transport, signaling, and plant-pest interactions. One long-term outcome will be the provision of a scientific basis for new strategies to protect plants from pest infestation. These new strategies carry the potential to dramatically reduce the amount of insecticides currently required in modern agriculture. In addition, broader impacts include education through teaching and textbook information on the mechanism of phloem transport and phloem insect interactions and through training of undergraduate and graduate students.

por.por_cntn:
Phloem is the name of the vascular tissue that transports carbohydrates from sites of synthesis to wherever they are needed by a plant. Phloem transport mainly occurs from the leaves, where carbohydrates are produced by photosynthesis, to the plant parts where they are stored or consumed. Storage organs include roots, fruits, and cereals which represent our major food sources. The phloem forms part of a plant's circulatory system and the impact of the phloem on plant growth and function is similar to that of our own circulatory system on our health and physiology. In addition to the transport function, chemical and electrical signals are also transmitted through the phloem. The mechanism of electrical signal transmission is very similar to that of our nervous system. The goal of this study was to examine the mechanism of phloem transport, unloading, the interconnection of the translocating tubes, and their impact on signal transduction.

In 1930, Ernst Munch proposed what is now known as the pressure flow hypothesis to explain fluid transport through the phloem. According to this hypothesis, a sugar-rich sap is pushed through the phloem tubes with the pressure being generated by an osmotic pump. The unloading process of the sugars is, however, little understood. The reason for this gap in knowledge is that the phloem is difficult to study, as the tubes are themselves living cells that cease transport if they are disturbed. While this has utility for the plant, in the same way that blood clotting plays an important role in our own bodies, it has made it difficult to obtain accurate measurements of the basic parameters of phloem function.

Previously we have developed a number of methods to study phloem in the living and translocating state. We have used these methods to study phloem unloading and signal transduction. We found that the current hypothesis on phloem unloading does not appear to be accurate. We conducted ultrastructural and physiological studies on unloading and found that there are connections (plasmodesmata) of different structure between certain cell interfaces and that this organization provides a filtration system in the unloading zone. The findings have led to a new hypothesis on phloem unloading. In addition we have gathered important information on tube connections and signal transduction. The tubes appear much more separated than previously expected.

The importance of our work relates to the central role played by the phloem in the plants that make up our food supply. At least 90% of the food we consume has been transported through the phloem and unloaded into a food source. Understanding the principles of unloading may enable us to direct phloem flow to locations of interest (e.g. fruits) within a plant to generate more and healthier food sources. In addition, the phloem is a major way in which viruses move through plants and aphids impale their mouth part directly into the phloem to feed on the sap which is rich in sugars and nutrients. Understanding the interaction and the signals that plants transmit in order to counteract a pest attack may help to find strategies to protect plants and to reduce application of chemicals.
